sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Burn: TOPICAL, apply 1% cream in 1/16-inch layer once or twice daily until healing or skin grafting

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in children

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no specific dosage adjustment of silver sulfADIAZINE is necessary; measurement of sulfADIAZINE levels may be indicated during prolonged use in patients with impaired renal function
  • hepatic impairment: no specific dosage adjustment of silver sulfADIAZINE is necessary; serum sulfonamide levels should be monitored during prolonged use in patients with impaired hepatic function

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to silver sulfADIAZINE or any component of the product
  • pregnancy (approaching or at term); sulfonamides may cause kernicterus
  • preterm infants or newborns 2 months of age or younger

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• blood dyscrasias (eg, agranulocytosis, aplastic anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, hemolytic anemia) may occur
  • CNS reactions may occur
  • cross-sensitivity with other sulfonamides may occur; if allergic reactions occur, consider potential hazards of continuing therapy
  • cutaneous reactions, life-threatening (eg, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis [TEN], exfoliative dermatitis), may occur
  • fungal proliferation, in or below the eschar, may occur
  • gastrointestinal reactions may occur
  • glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency; hemolysis may occur
  • hepatic or renal impairment; accumulation may occur; discontinuation may be necessary
  • hepatitis or hepatocellular necrosis may occur
  • toxic nephrosis may occur

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Erythema multiforme, Erythroderma, Mycosis, Skin necrosis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Hematologic:Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia, Hemolytic anemia
  • Hepatic:Hepatic necrosis, Hepatitis
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Renal:Interstitial nephritis, Nephrotoxicity

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Topical: Bactericidal for many gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. Mechanism of action differs from that of silver nitrate or sodium sulfADIAZINE. Acts only on the cell membrane and cell wall.
  • Also active against yeasts and Candida albicans (M. albicans).

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • apply under sterile conditions
  • burn areas should be covered at all times with cream; reapply whenever necessary
  • reapply immediately after hydrotherapy
  • dressings are not required but may be used

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduced ulcer
  • evidence of wound closure
  • CBC
  • renal function
  • serum sulfa levels
  • urinalysis for possible crystalluria (sulfa crystals)

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
OVERDOSE: Data limited. Effects may be an extension of adverse events reported with sulfonamides. Methemoglbinemia has been reported after overdose. ADVERSE EVENTS: Adverse reactions to sulfonamides can involve nearly every organ system; many effects appear to be hypersensitivity reactions, and are dose related. DERMATOLOGIC: Various dermatological reactions, including rash, pruritus, erythema nodosum, and quite severe and often fatal erythema multiforme of the Stevens-Johnson type have been reported. Lyell's Syndromes are usually associated with the use of a long-acting sulfonamides. GASTROINTESTINAL: Nausea and vomiting are common. HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTION: Transient myopia, conjunctivitis, hepatic injury, and keratitis may occur in association with a hypersensitivity reaction. NEUROLOGIC: Headache, depression, and hallucinations have been reported with therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Hypersensitivity reaction: For signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis administer oxygen, establish an airway, and give epinephrine and diphenhydramine as indicated.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV isotonic fluids at 10 to 20 mL/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Methemoglobinemia: Obtain a methemoglobin level. Treat symptomatic methemoglobinemia (usually at methemoglobin levels above 20% to 30%) with methylene blue and oxygen therapy.
  • Seizure: Seizures have been reported infrequently. Give benzodiazepines, barbiturates as indicated.
  • Monitoring of patient: Obtain a baseline CBC, electrolytes including glucose level and hepatic enzymes and renal function tests.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
TOXICITY: Methemoglobinemia has been reported after ingestion of 15 g sulfamethoxazole. Many of the adverse effects related to sulfonamides are hypersensitivity reactions, that develop at therapeutic doses. The incidence of adverse effects increases with higher doses. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies by agent.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Tell patient to avoid using this medicine on newborn infants under 2 months of age.
  • This drug may cause pruritus or skin irritation.
  • Advise patient to apply drug to skin only. Patient should avoid exposure of cream to the eyes.
  • Instruct patient on proper skin or wound preparation prior to application of drug.
